comments:
After launching eclipse with -clean and carry out certain operations, new plugins would not be able to be activated because MRUBundleFileList cannot remove the least frequently used bundle (stace trace as follow).  After some debugging, I found that there are entries inside the bundleFileList[] that are null.  As an experiment, I added the following code to the MRUBundleFileList.add() method around line 89 and it seems to get around the problem (I am not sure whether my code really solves the problem or just hides another problem in other component).

  if(toRemove!=null) {
    remove(toRemove);
    toRemove.close();
  }

This is the stack trace, after this problem happens, the whole workbench session is unusable because new plugin cannot be activated:

I assume you have set the osgi.bundlefile.limit property.  What value did you set it to?

Do you have repeatable steps I can use to reproduce?

Based on my System.out.println, the fileLimit is initialized to 100 which probably implies the osgi.bundlefile.limit is set to 100 as well.

I will send you an email with the test steps.

There is a synchronization issue in ZipBundleFile that will allow the same ZipFile to be opened more than once.  This ultimately causes the same BundleFile to be added more than once to the MRUBundleFileList which will cause this error to occur.

Created an attachment (id=47874)
patch

prevents the same ZipFile from being opened more than once.
Jeff, do you approve this for 3.2.1?  Without it the osgi.bundlefile.limit will cause failures.  Also this bug can cause open ZipFile objects to leak.
Tom's dyslexia keeps causing him to pick 3.1.2 from the target milestone pull down instead of 3.2.1 :-)

(In reply to comment #4)
> Created an attachment (id=47874) [edit]
> patch
> 
> prevents the same ZipFile from being opened more than once.
> 

Unfortunately, this does not go far enought to make ZipBundleFile thread-safe. The zipFile field is still not treated in a thread-safe way.

However the patch does seem to make access to the closed field thread-safe.
+1 for the concept of fixing this problem in 3.2.1.  I will defer to BJ for code reviews as he is already digging in.  If he is happy I am happy...

Hi Thomas and BJ,

I tested the patch and it seems to resolve the problem.  Given BJ's comment, are we going to have another patch?

Regards,

Kelvin

Created an attachment (id=47911)
3.2.1 patch

This patch is against the 3.2.1 maintenance branch.  It makes both close and zipFile fields thread-safe.

+1 for the 3.2.1 patch. All entry points to the class which need to be synchronized are either synchronized or documented that external synchronization is necessary.

For 3.3, more work is needed. This class (and related classes) are too promiscuous with internal state. Most protected members should be made private to better encapsulate shared state. Such changes are not desireable for 3.2.x since they change the class signature.
The patch (with additional javadoce changes) has been released to 3.2.1 maintenance branch and HEAD.
Sorry for the spam, forgot to resolve to FIXED.
Verified the fix has resolved the problem.
